shortDescription: A minor change in a design may alter user behaviour in ways that are hard to detect in a usability test. An A/B test allows you to compare real-world user behaviour across different versions of a product.
title: A/B Testing

shortDescription: To test hypotheses based on quantitative dataset
title: Inferential statistics

shortDescription: Gain insights by measuring and analysing data. Researching a dataset can give you useful quantitative information about the topic of interest.
title: Data analytics

shortDescription: Hardware does not always perform according to its specifications. Hardware validation ensures that the hardware performs as expected and excludes hardware as a source of errors.
title: Hardware validation

shortDescription: Computer simulations are used when a real-world process, system or event situation is not available or feasible.
title: Computer simulation

shortDescription: Detect problems users have with your solution and correct them before the system goes live.
title: Usability testing

shortDescription: Solve problems before your system goes into production and demonstrate that the system operates according to its requirements.
title: System test

shortDescription: In a component test, you test whole components or subsystems, instead of the atomic chunks of code that you test in unit tests. Test the component against its input and output relations (e.g. specified via interfaces). Component testing compares the outputs with expected results given pre-defined inputs.
title: Component test

shortDescription: Find certain types of bugs as early as possible and ensure your code keeps running after a change.
title: Unit test

shortDescription: Test the operating conditions under which the system delivers its intended functions.
title: Non-functional test

shortDescription: Understand the security risks of an IT system.
title: Security test

shortDescription: Generate and develop new ideas.
title: Brainstorm

shortDescription: Gain inspiration from your users by involving them in the design process. Co-creation may lead to unexpected and sensible project outcomes.
title: Co-creation

shortDescription: To find new solutions, be able to try them out quickly and involve many people in your challenge.
title: Hackathon

shortDescription: Understand why a problem occurs and prevent it from happening again.
title: Root cause analysis

shortDescription: To define and weigh the requirements of a new design or redesign, considering the interests of all concerned stakeholders.
title: Requirements engineering

shortDescription: Compare an actual situation to an ideal or desired situation. The gap analysis can be used to create plans to bridge the gaps.
title: Gap analysis

shortDescription: Breaking a complex IT system or problem into smaller parts ensures its maintainability and robustness, and facilitates cooperation in large-scale software projects.
title: Decomposition

shortDescription: Improve the quality of complex decisions.
title: Multi-criteria decision making

shortDescription: Maximize the outcome of your efforts or investment.
title: Business case exploration

shortDescription: Develop, evaluate or communicate a concept, design or problem solution to make your ideas concrete, to learn whether they work and to discover the technical limitations or possibilities.
title: Prototyping

shortDescription: With many eyeballs on the code, all bugs are shallow. Colleagues can help you find bugs and improve the quality of your source code.
title: Code review

shortDescription: Defining the IT architecture is complex and requires contributions from and interactions between software designers and/or architects. Sketching facilitates these discussions.
title: IT architecture sketching

shortDescription: A standardised set allows you to compare your product to similar products.
title: Benchmark test

shortDescription: Conforming to guidelines and standards helps ensure the credibility of the quality of your product and prevents reliability, privacy and security issues.
title: Guideline conformity analysis

shortDescription: Get an impression of how well your code is written and quickly find vulnerabilities, weak spots and bad smells.
title: Static program analyis

shortDescription: Ensure that the product is perfect before it is released to the client or users.
title: Product review

shortDescription: Get an idea of the unique selling points of the opportunity you have found, or of the idea you have to tackle a problem, and practice concise communication about them.
title: Pitch

shortDescription: Norms and values differ between various people and societies. Make sure your design and development decisions do not lead to conflicts with certain norms and values.
title: Ethical check

shortDescription: Colleagues and experts can help improve your work, especially if they need to reuse it.
title: Peer review

shortDescription: Documentation produced by the company can be a great first resource for understanding the organisation you are working for and their work processes.
title: Document analysis

shortDescription: To get an overview and summary of a dataset.
title: Descriptive statistics

shortDescription: Map the domain that your product will be part of, so you know the key concepts and the relations between them.
title: Domain modelling

shortDescription: Before solving a problem, it is important to understand it. Moreover, problem analysis ensures that you are not solving the wrong problem.
title: Problem analysis

shortDescription: Efficiently gather opinions and experiences through group discussions with stakeholders, users or experts.
title: Focus group

shortDescription: Get a feeling for how your intended users will use your product by unobtrusively observing them and their behaviour in their daily environment.
title: Observation

shortDescription: Understand the structure, flow or other aspects of a certain task. Task analysis focuses on what end users actually do to achieve their goals.
title: Task analysis

shortDescription: Get a detailed view of how users will be using your solution and what their requirements are. How Talk to your clients about their expectations and describe how the different users (or stakeholders) will interact with the system under development. It is highly recommended that you directly involve end users, rather than just the client.
title: Explore user requirements

shortDescription: Identify the stakeholders and ensure that their needs are considered.
title: Stakeholder analysis

shortDescription: Collect information (mostly quantitative) from a large sample of your target group.
title: Survey

shortDescription: Learn from potential users of your new product and other stakeholders.
title: Interview

shortDescription: Find out if what you are planning to do has already been done (in full or in part) by someone else.
title: Available product analysis

shortDescription: Incorporating what has proven to work somewhere else forms the basis of any high-quality project.
title: Best good and bad practices

shortDescription: A domain expert can put you on the right track when you enter a new domain or field of expertise. The expert can recommend sources, give you a sense of direction or point out common pitfalls.
title: Expert interview

shortDescription: Applying well-known design patterns improves the quality (and structure) of the designed software.
title: Design pattern research

shortDescription: Have others already tackled the problem? Incorporating your peersâ€™ knowledge can seriously speed things up.
title: Community research

shortDescription: A SWOT analysis supports decision makers in identifying relevant factors for achieving certain goals.
title: SWOT analysis

shortDescription: Find a niche or unique selling point competitors are not filling.
title: Competitive analysis

shortDescription: Find general information, guidance and best practices.
title: Literature study
